\begin{abstract}
In this note we argue that the galactic model chosen by E.-J.~Ahn, G.~Medina-Tanco, P.L.~Bierman and T.~Stanev 
in their paper discussing the origin of the highest energy cosmic rays, is alone responsible for the focusing of positive particles towards 
the North galactic pole. We discuss the validity of this model, in particular in terms of field reversals and radial extensions.
We conclude that with such a model one cannot retreive any directional information from the observed direction of the cosmic rays.
In particular one cannot identify point sources at least up to energies of about 200~EeV\footnotemark\ . Therefore the apparent clustering of the back-traced
highest energy cosmic rays observed to date cannot be interpreted as an evidence for a point source nor for the identification of M87, 
which happens to be close to the North pole, as being such a source.
\vspace{1pc}
\end{abstract
title: Note on the Origin of the Highest Energy Cosmic Rays.
